body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

you can do this yourself

http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/core/functions.html?highlight=function#sqlalchemy.sql.functions.GenericFunction


```
class array_agg(GenericFunction):
    type = ARRAY
```

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

oh you need to pass it through, then this one:
```
from sqlalchemy.sql.functions import ReturnTypeFromArgs
class array_agg(ReturnTypeFromArgs):
    pass

```

feel free to test the feature there and let me know if _type_from_args() works in the case of ARRAY(something).

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **title** from "Please add array_agg function" to "Please add array_agg function  (add a series of PG"

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **milestone** from "0.x.xx" to "1.x.xx"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

array_agg is also SQL standard, here's DB2, http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSEPEK_11.0.0/com.ibm.db2z11.doc.sqlref/src/tpc/db2z_bif_arrayagg.dita, and for that matter, ARRAYs themselves are SQL standard, to have this in core we'd need something array-like in base types.

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* removed labels: **low priority**

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* removed labels: **postgres**
* added labels: **sql**

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **milestone** from "1.x.xx" to "1.1"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- Added support for the SQL-standard function :class:`.array_agg`,
which automatically returns an :class:`.Array` of the correct type
and supports index / slice operations.   As arrays are only
supported on Postgresql at the moment, only actually works on
Postgresql. fixes #3132


→ cfae9c2eaf00

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

**Sebastian Bank ([@xflr6](https://github.com/xflr6)) wrote:**

Nice. Is it desired/possible to also support the `ORDER BY` clause of aggregates?

So far, I have been using variations of [this recipe](https://gist.github.com/gcarothers/5971471) for `array_agg` and also `string_agg`.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

I was really hoping this would just be the normal "WITHIN GROUP" thing I just did at https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/issues/1370/support-percentile_cont-other-ordered-set but unfortunately ORDER BY inside of a function argument like this is not SQL standard, and we don't put PG-specific things into the Core.  This would have to be postgresql.aggregate_order_by(expr, order_by) .  Please send a PR, thanks.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- add PG-specific aggregate_order_by(), references #3132


→ 5295a683f9ac

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

no PR needed thanks

**Sebastian Bank ([@xflr6](https://github.com/xflr6)) wrote:**

Thanks! (with `string_agg` the call looks a little suprising, right?)

Maybe the docs can give a hint to wrap `array_agg` in `type_coerce(..., postgresql.ARRAY)` if one wants to use `contains` or other postgres-specific methods.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- add a postgresql-specific form of array_agg() that injects the
ARRAY type, references #3132


→ 410be197ef5d

**jmagnusson ([@jmagnusson](https://github.com/jmagnusson)) wrote:**

@zzzeek Does `aggregate_order_by` somehow support multiple `ORDER BY` arguments in it's current form?

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

we can make that easier but for the moment you can send a list of items as a `sqlalchemy.sql.expression.ClauseList`.  Send a PR to make this more part of the API (see how Selectable.order_by does it).

issue.title: make part of PG ARRAY part of base types, look into ANY / ALL
issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek))**

ARRAY, array constructors, ANY, ALL, CONTAINS are all in DB2 as well not to mention the SQL standard.  Oracle has `VARRAY` also which maybe we could support someday.  this is needed for functions like #3132.

At the moment, PG still has its own operators like contains, contained_by, etc., so I still think people will want to use postgresql.ARRAY.  However, for #3132, we need to do a check on the input type to see if it is already Array.   So I think putting the basic expression stuff into sqltypes.Array would be helpful here, as would an implementation of ANY / ALL.  Ideally ANY/ALL would be able to accept subqueries as well, also SQL standard.  They are *close* to IN in that they accept a subquery in this way but not quite the same.
